en.Slide 1: Let's see how we can reach a closed form of the summation $\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}i$
en.Slide 2: As an example suppose we have $n = 5$
en.Slide 3.1: When $i=1$, this adds $1$ to the overall summation. This is represented by a single rectangle.
en.Slide 4.1: When $i = 2$, this adds $2$ to the overall summation. This is represented by two rectangles.
en.Slide 5.1: When $i = 3$, this adds $3$ to the overall summation. This is represented by three rectangles.
en.Slide 6.1: When $i = 4$, this adds $4$ to the overall summation. This is represented by four rectangles.
en.Slide 7.1: When $i = 5$, this adds $4$ to the overall summation. This is represented by four rectangles.
en.Slide 8: The closed form solution of this summation can be found by calculating the total surface area of the resulted shape
en.Slide 9: The total area will be the area of the big traingle
en.Slide 10:
+
The Sum of the areas of the $n$ small rectangles
en.Slide 11: So, the total area is $\frac{n^2}{2} + \frac{n}{2}$ which gives $\frac{n(n + 1)}{2}$
